scenario:
US homebuyers and refinancers showed a strong rebound last week, with total mortgage applications rising 11% for the week ending May 2, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This increase is the fourth largest weekly gain in 2025 so far, and signals a resurgence in housing market activity. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate for conforming loan balances eased to 6.84%, down from 6.89% a week earlier, triggering a wave of new demand.

Purchase applications increased by 11%, while refinance activity rose by the same margin. Year-over-year, refinancing volumes are now 51% higher, a dramatic swing after months of tepid activity. Government-backed loans, such as those insured by the Federal Housing Administration, also saw rising demand, with FHA purchase applications jumping 9%.

The economic news has been mixed, with solid employment gains in April, but negative first-quarter GDP growth and signs of contraction in the manufacturing sector. Investors expect the Federal Reserve to hold rates steady in the 4.25%-4.5% range during its upcoming policy meeting, with a 30% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut by June and a 75% chance of a potential easing by July.

Real estate equities have started to price in optimism, with the Real Estate Select Sector SPDR Fund XLRE climbing 0.8% in premarket trading, and other real estate stocks such as Public Storage PSA, Digital Realty Trust Inc. DLR, and Simon Property Group Inc. SPG gaining 1.6% or more. The iShares Mortgage Real Estate ETF REZ jumped 2.3% after hours Tuesday.
